awd_titl_txt: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: The dynamics of socio-chemo cues across a contact zone in the California vole (Microtus californicus)
awd_abstract_narration:
This study will investigate how evolution of olfactory (odor) cues helps maintain genetic differences between two recently evolved subspecies of the California vole. Voles, like many mammals, use olfactory cues to choose their mates. This can lead to behavioral isolation between groups of individuals (populations) and ultimately lead to genetic separation (divergence) and speciation. The researchers will document how olfactory cues change across a contact zone, an area where these two closely related vole species meet and potentially interbreed. Chemical profile data and genetic data will be collected from across the contact zone and then statistically compared to determine whether patterns mirror each other; a close correlation will suggest that chemical cues and mating preferences are responsible for genetic divergence. Studying contact zones between recently diverged subspecies can reveal important information about how species form and are maintained as distinct entities. In addition, the project will provide independent research opportunities for undergraduate students. Outreach includes the development of educational activities appropriate for public school students.

This project will characterize geographic variation in the olfactory cues used by two subspecies of the California vole, Microtus californicus, when choosing mates. The main goal is to determine if differences in olfactory cues are correlated with the degree of genetic differentiation between subspecies. The investigators will analyze urine samples collected from across a contact zone between the two sub-species. Chemical profiles (chemical composition and relative abundances) of volatile and semi-volatile molecules in urine samples will be quantified using solid-phase microextraction (SPME) coupled with gas chromatography-mass spectrometry. Cline analysis will be conducted to determine whether chemical changes reflect environmental differences (e.g. habitat differences or geographic gradients) or conversely whether they mirror the known genetic break between the two vole lineages. A pattern of geographic variation in urine chemical profiles that mirrors the genetic data would suggest that behavioral reproductive isolation contributes to maintaining these two genetically distinct lineages.

por.por_cntn:
During the process of speciation, diverging genetic lineages gradually become reproductively incompatible with one another, resulting in the eventual formation of distinct species. Patterns of mate choice may play a role in maintaining distinct genetic lineages and may also contribute to the process of speciation. Mammals often use olfactory cues when choosing mates and such cues have been linked to multiple aspects of mate choice, including selection of genetically compatible reproductive partners. This suggests that olfactory cues may differ as a function of genetic differences among populations or species. At the same time, olfactory cues are known to vary with environmental conditions, such as food resources. 

To understand how historical lineage divergence and current environmental conditions interact to shape variation in olfactory cues, this project investigated geographic differences in the relative abundances of volatile compounds in the urine of California voles (Microtus californicus). The geographic setting for this project was coastal California, including a contact zone between two recently diverged lineages of voles that occurs in Santa Barbara County. Using gas chromatography coupled with mass spectrometry (GC-MS), we sought to characterize variation in the relative abundances of volatile compounds in urine from free-living voles. Specifically, we sought to determine if this variation was consistent with predictions based on (1) levels of genetic differentiation among populations (odor-gene covariance hypothesis), (2) enhanced differences between lineages in the contact zone (character displacement), (3) greater differentiation with increasing geographic distance (isolation by distance), and (4) differences in gut microbiome composition (bacterial hypothesis).

Our analyses revealed that within the northern lineage of voles, overall chemical profiles differed between populations outside of versus within the contact zone, providing potential support for character displacement. At the level of individual components of urine, we found the same pattern for two unidentified volatile compounds. In contrast, in the southern lineage, no differences were found among populations within versus outside of the contact zone. This outcome partially supports the prediction of character displacement hypothesis. Variation of overall chemical profiles did not recapitulate genetic differentiation among populations or between the northern and southern lineage. This result suggests chemical cues do not co-vary with genetic lineages. The relative abundances of several compounds varied with season, sampling locality and gut microbial composition, suggesting that factors affecting the composition of urine may be compound specific. Future studies that examine the functional significance of individual volatile compounds should elucidate the evolution of these complex olfactory cues. 

The outcomes of this project demonstrate that olfactory cues in urine may be affected by environmental factors, such as climate or gut microbial composition of an individual. More importantly, olfactory cues in urine reflect differences between genetically differentiated populations or lineages. This suggests that olfactory cues may be important in preventing exchange of genetic materials between distinct lineages or species. Furthermore, our result also suggests that such sexual selection may be asymmetric between the two genetic lineages since only one lineage showed differences between populations from within and outside the contact zone. This project has generated novel insights into how selection shapes reproductive barriers between sister taxa at genetic, biochemical and organismal levels. It has also laid the groundwork for future studies aimed at understanding how olfactory communication contributes to the generation of diversity in mammals.
